title-group.article-title: Design of tunable notch filter based on plasmonic and InGaAsP waveguide

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: A highly efficient compact tunable optical notch filter is proposed and analyzed using the 2D Finite Element Method (FEM). The proposed structure consists of a slanted stub plasmonic resonator, Metal–Insulator–Metal (MIM) waveguide, and InGaAsP as a third-order non-linear optical material. By altering the pumping state of the InGaAsP, the filtered wavelengths may be easily controlled continuously over 200 nm a range. The suggested notch filter can remove four narrow bands of wavelengths, each around 50 nm wide, and a transmission of about − 17 dB. The proposed filter’s key advantages are its high transmission coefficient and fabrication simplicity with compact size. For future integrated plasmonic devices such as outdoor visible light communications and optical imaging, the proposed filter can be manufactured using an oblique angle shadow evaporation technique.

custom-meta.meta-value: Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Plasmonics is the creation, detection, and control of optical signals at nanometer-scale metal-dielectric interactions. Field enhancement and tight field confinement are two of plasmonics' key characteristics. The former permits a covert interaction between light and matter (Kim et al. 2022).Surface plasmons (SPs) are electromagnetic waves that are created when a collective of free electrons oscillate at the metal–dielectric interface. Surface Plasmon Polariton (SPPs) is a surface plasmon coupled with a photon which causes these light waves to be propagated and trapped through the metal–dielectric interface (Barnes et al. 2003; Wang et al. 2015). Therefore, SPPs have been used in various applications such as energy harvesting (Hussein et al. 2014; Mescia 2015), filtering (Abd-Elsamee et al. 2022), data storage (El-Rabiaey et al. 2016), sensing (Khani and Hayati 2021), and absorbers (Areed et al. 2018). Plasmonics-based fiber-optic sensors (fiber SPP) provide remarkable sensitivity, resolution, fast response, small size, and real time detection capabilities due to their excellent plasmon-matter interaction (Zhang et al. 2019; Hao et al. 2022a, b; Hao et al. 2022a, b). Fiber SPP sensor has been used in wide applications such as environmental monitoring (Shao et al. 2018), disease diagnosis (Lidiya et al. 2019), and biological analysis (Wang and Wang 2018). Therefore, there are various types of SPR-based optical fiber sensors, including tapered fibers, unclad fibers, and fiber Bragg grating (FBG) which have the ability of remote sensing without electricity and the ability to be used in flammable and hazardous environments (Hosoki et al. 2022). One of the fiber SPP sensors limitations is the complexity in fabrication during the process of depositing the metallic layer inside or outside the fiber structure (Rifat, Ahmed et al. 2017).

Recently, numerous plasmonic waveguides (PWGs) have been studied with different structure designs, such as chains of nanoparticles (Azzam et al. 2014, Nurmohammadi, Abbasian et al. 2018a, b; Wu et al. 2021), metal films (Islam et al. 2017), metal grooves hybrid Bragg waveguide (Lu et al. 2012; Zhou et al. 2020), metal–insulator-metal (MIM) slabs (Heikal et al. 2019), and insulator–metal-insulator IMI slabs (Park et al. 2010). Beyond the diffraction limit of light, all these waveguides effectively confine electromagnetic energy tightly near the interface. Metal–insulator-metal (MIM) and insulator–metal-insulator (IMI) structures are two classic kinds of the plasmonic waveguide. The MIM structure is suitable and attractive for on-chip integration into PICs due to its strong light confinement with significant propagation (Ebadi et al. 2020) and also easy to implement with recent fabrication technologies such as focused ion beam, lithography, etching, and template methods (Bayati et al. 2010; Cai et al. 2012; Khani et al. 2021). Based on the aforementioned features, a collection of PWGs based on the MIM structure has been proposed and reported, such as filters (Almewafy et al. 2019), sensors (Azab et al. 2017; Alagdar et al. 2020; Sarhan et al. 2020), absorbers (Areed et al. 2016; Areed et al. 2016), and more. Therefore, a variety of plasmonic applications based on MIM waveguides filters are designed such as multipurpose filters (Ebadi et al. 2020), tunable band-gap filters (Zhai et al. 2013), selective visible band filters (Pinton et al. 2018), near-infrared filter (Mao et al. 2017), double mode wavelength filter (Zegaar et al. 2022), refractive index sensors (Salah et al. 2021), bio-sensor (Hocini et al. 2021), and optical switching (Paul and Ray 2019; Khani et al. 2021).

Plasmonic notch filters based on the MIM waveguide have been designed, such as circular ring resonators (Setayesh et al. 2011, Kamari et al. 2021a, b), Brag grating (Sharma and Dinesh 2017), intersected double-ring resonators (Hocini et al. 2020), tooth cavity (Lin and Huang 2009; Chau et al. 2020), and double-sided nano desk with double slot cavities (Qi et al. 2019). The transmission spectrum of these filters introduces a wide band stop with a fixed filtering channel. For the active control of the optical signal in the plasmonic filters, optical nonlinear materials have great potential in that field due to their ultrafast response time and high bandwidth with low energy consumption (Li et al. 2016a, 2018). Additionally, when these nonlinear materials with appropriate dimensions are combined with a plasmonic structure can give rise to new hybrid metal-dielectric media for frequency generation in neglected regions of the electromagnetic spectrum which have been known as strategic techniques for designing ultracompact and intense light sources (Ahmadivand et al. 2018; Ahmadivand and Gerislioglu 2021) and also, for optical switching (Kong et al. 2017; Nurmohammadi, Abbasian et al. 2018a, b). Many nonlinear materials have been previously utilized to design tunable notch filters such as graphene (Nasari and Abrishamian 2014; Li et al. 2016a, b; Heydari and Samiei 2020) and Au∶SiO2 (Arianfard et al. 2016).

This paper presents an efficient and simple single-slanted stub resonator waveguide for notch filtering applications. The finite element numerical method (FEM, COMSOL MULTIPHYSICS, Version 5.5) is used to simulate the performance of the proposed plasmonic notch filter. A notch filter can be simply designed with a desired resonance “trapped” wavelength by increasing the length of the slanted stub resonator to be worked in visible light communication systems (Vitasek et al. 2016) and as RGB filter in CCD camera (Kaplan et al. 2011). To make this filter adjustable, the dielectric material "Air" was filled by a nonlinear material (InGaAsP). The incident light intensity to the InGaAsP controls the notch wavelength of the plasmonic filter. As a result, four tiny regions of wavelengths, each roughly 50 nm wide and with a transmission of about − 17 dB, can be removed based on the intensity of the incident light. The suggested plasmonic filter can have its wavelengths tuned without modifying its geometrical structure, making it appropriate for integrated circuit designs. The results of the proposed filter have been compared with similar structures. The comparison reveals that the proposed filter not only has the advantage of being simple/compact but also has more trapped wavelengths with narrow bands and minimum transmission. The static and tunable notch filters are sought to be the best designs for working in the visible and near-infrared spectrum with a simple and compact structure.

sec.title: Static notch filter
sec.p:
The term "Static" means that filtration occurs at fixed/specific wavelengths. As shown in Fig. 1, the proposed Plasmonic Notch Filter (PNF) consists of a MIM-WG coupled to a single-slanted stub resonator. The PNF insulator and metal layers are set to be air (εd = 1) and silver (Ag), respectively. Silver has been selected in the proposed design since it is a dominant conductor for optical and near-infrared ranges. The silver permittivity (εm) can be obtained and expressed by Johnson and Christy measurements (Johnson and Christy 1972). Table 1 summarizes the optimum dimensions of the proposed PNF which are determined from the parametric analysis. The calculation of the propagation properties of this structure is based on the 2D FEM method (Rajarajan et al. 2000; Obayya et al. 2001; Anwar et al. 2002). The 2D model has been selected rather than 3D one to save computer resources and shorten simulation times. The involvement of the structure's height in the losses of the 3D model can be approximated by a 2D one, despite the device height being far greater than the skin depth of SPPs (Chao et al. 2021). Therefore, if the structure is assumed mathematically to be infinite in the third dimension, the influence of the substrate thickness on the results obtained can be ignored (Hocini et al. 2019). For numerical convergence, Table 2 summarizes the values of the normalized transmitted power at λ = 580 nm according to the element mesh size. This table illustrates that this structure must be discretized in the x and y directions using a quadratic shape function with an extremely fine mesh element size to obtain a numerical convergence.Fig. 1

sec.title: Tunable notch filter
Pumping InGaAsP for a tunable plasmonic notch filter
sec.p:
Ensuring the validity of the simulations, the effect of the biasing light used to modify the InGaAsP properties has been studied using the FEM numerical method in the presence of stub and bus plasmonic waveguide. A sinusoidal pump wave at 192 THz (1562.5 nm) is excited to the left of the structure with a rise time of 100 fs (Fujii et al. 2006a, b). The detected value of the electric field reads about 1.4 × 105 v/m which is comparable to the value obtained in (Fujii et al. 2006a, b). This sinusoidal wave is applied (stimuli) to the nonlinear medium to modify its characteristics. From Fig. 2, it is observed that the electric field lines are parallel in a uniform manner and not affected by the plasmonic holes. In other words, there is no interference between the filter input wave and the pump light.Fig. 2
Capture the electric field when pumping InGaAsP with 192 THz (1562.5) sinusoidal wave

sec.title: Concept of operations and results
sec.p:
Initially, the variation of the stub rotation angle (θ) has been studied while ws and d are kept constant at 50 nm and 150 nm respectively. One can see from Fig. .3a, e that with angles 0° and 180° (horizontal position) there is no coupling between the stub resonator and bus WG. No resonance dip happens, and all wavelengths are passed through MIM WG. Changing the angle θ from 45° to 90°, the bandgap is widened, and the resonance dip wavelength is redshifted, see Fig. 3b, c. Changing the angle θ from 90° to 135°, multiple resonances have been observed due to the Fano resonance where destructive interference occurs between the bus waveguide and slanted stub resonator, see Fig. 3d.Fig. 3
Transmission spectra for a single stub resonator filter with different angle θ: aθ = 0°, bθ = 45°, cθ = 90°, dθ = 135°, eθ = 180°. Inset: schematic plot of MIM filter with single stub resonator. The stub length and width are fixed at 50 nm,150 nm, respectively

sec.title: Static notch filter
sec.p:
Based on the prior observations from Fig. 3, the stub rotation angle has been chosen to be equal 45° which has a single trapped optical wavelength with a narrower bandwidth. Figure 4a shows the transmission spectrum of the proposed static PNF with the tuned dimensions shown in Fig. 1. Figure 4b illustrates that the notch wavelength (λ = 580 nm) is trapped inside the slanted stub causing a minimum of transmission of about 0.02 (− 17 dB). The filter insertion loss for the pass and stop wavelength is 0.123 dB and 17.21 dB, respectively. In the case of the non-existence of a slanted stub resonator, all the wavelengths are passed through the waveguide structure, see Fig. 4c.Fig. 4
a transmitted power in dB, transmission field distribution of the modal analysis: b with stub, c without stub

sec.title: Tunable notch filter
Comparison with previous filter designs
sec.p:
Table 4 compares the proposed notch filter and the previous filter design. In comparison to the findings in (Monks et al. 2016; Hocini et al. 2020), the static PNF (d = 300 nm) achieves minimal transmission values at the trapped wavelengths and acceptable minimum transmission values for the other filter designs. In addition, the static PNF has a minimum bandwidth = of 40 nm. Another proposed tunable PNF can remove four narrow bands of wavelengths, each around 50 nm wide, and transmit at about − 17 dB over a tuning range reached to 200 nm. According to what was presented, the tunable PNF presents a better specification than the finding presented in (Arianfard et al. 2016).Table 4

sec.title: Fabrication tolerance
sec.p:
Oblique Angle Shadow Evaporation technology (Gu et al. 2018) has been recommended to fabricate the PNF structure. The advantage of the oblique angle shadow evaporation approach is that the second evaporation metal does not have to be the same as the first evaporation metal, allowing heterogeneous nano-gap structures to be created by modifying the second evaporation metal. Heterogeneous nanostructures feature a substantial electromagnetic field enhancement and are also simple to functionalize. This suggests that oblique angle shadow evaporation could have a lot of applications in surface-enhanced spectroscopy, optical trapping (filtering), and sensing (Gu et al. 2018). The oblique angle shadow evaporation technique can fabricate the proposed structure by Suspending the mask above the substrate and regulating the deposition angle to be oblique to the surface normal. Furthermore, a similar configuration of slanted stub resonators was previously numerically analyzed and fabricated (Zilio et al. 2015). Since the shape of the nanosized plasmonic waveguide is sensitive to fabrication faults (Jung 2017), fabrication tolerances must be considered. The fabrication tolerance of the proposed PNF was investigated by changing the value of the single slanted stub angle "θ ", length "d ", and width "ws ". Figure 9a illustrates how the first factor" θ " affected the performance of the proposed PNF. It has been noticed that in any angle deviation within the range of ± 4° from the original angle value "45°", there is no change in the filter transmission spectrum, which demonstrates good tolerance and stability. The filter transmission spectrum at the notch wavelength is affected by the width and length variation of the single-slanted stub resonator, as shown in Fig. 9b and c. For both single-slanted stub width and length variation, it has been observed that there is a slight shifting in the filter transmission spectrum. Therefore, for good stability of the proposed PNF, the tolerance value due to the variation of the slanted stub width and length dimensions must be within ± 2 nm from its original values. Another important issue in plasmonic nanostructure fabrication is the interaction between the emitter and plasmonic nanostructure. Since the interaction of light with metal nanostructure in free space is a very weak process. Therefore, there are many methods to enhance the strength of light-matter interaction near the material surface. One of the promising techniques is the mesoscopic quantum dots QDs which enhances the plasmon excitation rate. This enhancement happens when placing QDs in metallic nanostructures that enable strong confinement of light and thereby enhance the light-matter interaction (Andersen et al. 2011; Gonçalves et al. 2020).Fig. 9
Fabrication tolerance due to the variation of the single slanted stub resonator's a deposition angle " θ ", b width "ws", and c length "d", in the PNF structure. Inset: the transmission value variation at the notch wavelength λ = 580 nm

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A single-slanted stub plasmonic resonator based on Metal–Insulator-Metal (MIM) waveguide has been numerically analyzed using 2D FEM. Static PNF, which contains air as a dielectric medium, trapped a single wavelength ( λ = 580 nm) inside the slanted stub causing a minimum transmission of about 0.02. For the pass and stop wavelengths, the insertion loss of the static PNF is 0.123 dB and 17.21 dB, respectively. A notch filter can be simply designed with any desired “trapped” wavelength by varying the slanted stub length. This filter can be utilized in visible light communication systems and RGB filters in CCD cameras. Filling an air medium with a nonlinear dielectric material (InGaAsP) that can be manipulated in the visible and near IR spectra will result in a tunable plasmonic notch filter. By increasing the pumping light intensity which is exposed to the nonlinear medium, the stop wavelength ranges are shifted to longer wavelength bands with a tunability range of 200 nm. The proposed tunable PNF can remove four narrow bands of wavelengths, each around 50 nm wide with a minimum transmitting power of about − 17 dB. The proposed filter structure is significantly smaller than similar structures with a more simplistic architecture. The oblique angle shadow evaporation technique has been recommended to perform the fabrication process of the presented PNF which offers a good fabrication tolerance.
